feed.title: Development in Galaxy
feed.subtitle: Recently added tutorials, slides, FAQs, and events in the dev topic

entry.title: üìö Creation of an interactive Galaxy tools table for your community
entry.summary: Galaxy offers thousands of tools. They are developed across various GitHub repositories. Furthermore, Galaxy also embraces granular implementation of software tools as sub-modules. In practice, this means that tool suites are separated into Galaxy tools, also known as wrappers, that capture their component operations. Some key examples of suites include Mothur and OpenMS, which translate to tens and even hundreds of Galaxy tools.

entry.title: üìö Adding and updating best practice metadata for Galaxy tools using the bio.tools registry
entry.summary: Galaxy offers thousands of tools. Many of these tools either have incomplete metadata or are not yet linked to sources of high-quality metadata such as bio.tools.

entry.title: üìö Writing Automated Tests for Galaxy
entry.summary: The Galaxy code base contains thousands of tests that include tests of different types (unit vs. functional vs. end-to-end; client vs. backend, etc.) that are supported by a variety of testing frameworks and libraries. In this tutorial, we will offer a small, yet representative sample of the types of tests you might write, as well as the concepts and issues you may need to be familiar with when writing tests for Galaxy code, whether as part of a new feature you are implementing, or as a standalone contribution to Galaxy‚Äôs testing code.

entry.title: üìö Scripting Galaxy using the API and BioBlend
entry.summary: BioBlend (Sloggett et al. 2013) is a Python library to enable simple interaction with Galaxy (Afgan et al. 2018) via the command line or scripts.

entry.title: ‚ùì When I try to run a Selenium test, I get an error
entry.summary: If you get the following error:

entry.title: ‚ùì Is the ToolFactory a complete replacement for manual tool building?
‚ùì Only one Planemo test runs at a time. Why doesn't the server allow more than one at once?
‚ùì I cannot run client tests because yarn is not installed.
entry.summary: Make sure you have executed scripts/common_startup.sh and have activated the virtual environment (. .venv/vin/activate) in your current terminal session.

entry.title: ‚ùì Why do I need that big (~5GB!) complicated Docker thing - can I just install the ToolFactory into our local galaxy server from the toolshed?
entry.summary: You can but it can‚Äôt really be very useful. The ToolFactory is a Galaxy tool, but it installs newly generated tools automatically into the local Galaxy server. This is not normally possible because a tool cannot escape Galaxy‚Äôs job execution environment isolation. The ToolFactory needs to write to the normally forbidden server‚Äôs configuration so the new tool appears in the tool menu and is installed in the TFtools directory which is a subdirectory of the Galaxy tools directory.

entry.title: ‚ùì First job I submitted remains grey or running for a long time - is it broken?
‚ùì Where can I get planemo?
‚ùì What file/data formats are defined for I/O in Galaxy?
‚ùì `docker-compose up` fails with error `/usr/bin/start.sh: line 133: /galaxy/.venv/bin/uwsgi: No such file or directory`
‚ùì My Rscript tool generates a strange R error on STDOUT about an invalid operation on a closure called 'args' ?
entry.summary: Did your code declare the args vector with something like args = commandArgs(trailingOnly=TRUE) before it tried to access args[1] ?

entry.title: ‚ùì I want to use a collection for outputs but it always passes the test even when the script fails. Why?
‚ùì The folder `recipes/belerophon/` and the file `meta.yaml` already exist in bioconda?
entry.summary: The recipe has already been added previously. If you want to create the recipe from scratch you may just do this in another directory below recipes/.

entry.title: ‚ùì How to Contribute to Galaxy
entry.summary: Contributing to Galaxy is a multi-step process, this will guide you through it.

entry.title: üìö Debugging Galaxy
entry.summary: In this tutorial we will demonstrate how to find and fix common types of bugs you may encounter as a contributor to Galaxy. We will step you through the process of finding and fixing a bug - from locating specific errors in the logs of Galaxy‚Äôs GitHub Actions, to identifying their cause, developing a solution and committing your edits

entry.title: üìö Contributing a New Feature to Galaxy Core
entry.summary: This tutorial walks you through developing an extension to Galaxy, and how to contribute back to the core project.
